title: How fossil corals can shed light on the Earth's past climate
text:
The last ice age July 3, 2014 
A team of scientists has discovered that a giant 'burp' of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the North Pacific Ocean helped trigger the end of last ice age, around 17,000 years ago. Corals provide clues for climate change research July 16, 2014 
(Phys.org) —Just as growth rings can offer insight into climate changes occurring during the lifespan of a tree, corals have much to tell about changes in the ocean. At Caltech, climate scientists Jess F. Adkins and Nivedita ... New study shows three abrupt pulse of carbon dioxide during last deglaciation October 29, 2014 
A new study shows that the rise of atmospheric carbon dioxide that contributed to the end of the last ice age more than 10,000 years ago did not occur gradually, but was characterized by three "pulses" in which C02 rose abruptly. Permafrost soil: Possible source of abrupt rise in greenhouse gases at end of last Ice Age November 20, 2014 
Scientists from the Alfred Wegener Institute, Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research (AWI) have identified a possible source of carbon dioxide (CO2) and other greenhouse gases that were abruptly released to the atmosphere ... Carbon release from ocean helped end the Ice Age February 11, 2015 
A release of carbon dioxide from the deep ocean helped bring an end to the last Ice Age, according to new research led by the University of Southampton. Copepod migrations are important for the ocean's uptake of CO2 September 9, 2015 
In a scientific article recently published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), researchers from DTU Aqua, the University of Copenhagen and the University of Strathclyde, Scotland, have shown that the ... Tiny plankton can play a major role in CO2 storage in the oceans September 24, 2015 
Tiny zooplankton animals, each no bigger than a grain of rice, may be playing a huge part in regulating climate change, research involving the University of Strathclyde has found. Nearly half of US seafood supply is wasted September 23, 2015

Trees, crucial absorbers of climate-harming carbon dioxide gas, may finally be balking at an ever-earlier spring season brought on by global warming, researchers said Wednesday. Researchers reveal when global warming first appeared September 22, 2015
